list.name: 变更
list.comment:
1. Simplify the model, Only two class: --Agent class for G/S/T --Landscape class for 4-state landscape
2. Agents all search on the finest landscape, just perceiving it from different perspectives. --adopt the default element design, resonating with the mindset and cognitive fixation; perhaps removed. --adopt the shelter "*" element design, resonating with the myopia induced ambiguity.
3. Introduce the different sub-area in the landscape, removed.
4. Adjust the ambiguity design --the average pooling algorithm now is much more informative and consistent with neighborhood perception.

component.name: FlaskConsoleOptions
component.custom-start-script: import sys sys.path.extend([WORKING_DIR_AND_PYTHON_PATHS]) from flask.cli import ScriptInfo locals().update(ScriptInfo(create_app=None).load_app().make_shell_context()) print("Python %s on %s\nApp: %s [%s]\nInstance: %s" % (sys.version, sys.platform, app.import_name, app.env, app.instance_path))

option.name: myCustomStartScript
option.value: import sys sys.path.extend([WORKING_DIR_AND_PYTHON_PATHS]) from flask.cli import ScriptInfo locals().update(ScriptInfo(create_app=None).load_app().make_shell_context()) print("Python %s on %s\nApp: %s [%s]\nInstance: %s" % (sys.version, sys.platform, app.import_name, app.env, app.instance_path))

task.summary: 默认任务

Volidate the Multi-State Landscape -- is there any inherent differences between binary and polynary landscape (e.g., distribution, variance, quantiles, max-min, etc)? -> Yes, G landscape is more smooth and concentrated (average pooling concentrate the distribution) -- will full S outperform full G for certainty? -> Full G > Full S -- will G and S with the same amount of knowledge perform differently? -> Partial G < Partial S -- will the performance always increase with increasing knowledge (tunable elements)
-> These conclusions are based on the average pooling. In other words, the payoff is randomly assigned (expectation is the same), rather than damage if decisions are not made. The difference is the variance, randomly generated values lead to higher variance, whereas average pooling lead to smaller variance. Yet, we believe smaller variance is more reasonable for modeling generalists and shallow understandings. This average pooling is coherent with the NK model, recalling the integration from FC into fitness; More importantly, normal distribution is common adopted in social phenomenon. This tradition are strongly built on normal distribution, unless strong reasons are provided (e.g., Levinthal's (2022) Organizational Task Environments). In this paper, we stay in the tradition of normal distribution. One can extend our model to explore the boundaries of this paper. -> If the assumptions are challenged, the conclusion may be different-> Partial knowledge is always harmful. Yet, there are many cases where one can stay ambiguious; In fact, this also resonate with the focusing problem-solving. In fact, if we release the scope constrains, G and S will continuous to improve their performance. Thus, we are not arguing that increasing knowledge is harmful. Instead, we are saying that tuning all the elements at the same time is harmful. Simplified caricatures help the search to jump out of the local traps. Thus, the question comes as to the trade-off between focusing and divergency. How many elements should generalists and specialists handles?
--recall the unknown domain shelter "*" -- If not applicable, may roll back to default value setups --Design separate CogLandscape class --Comparing the search trajectories among cog, ave, max, and min fitness values

Volidate the Multi-State Landscape -- is there any inherent differences between binary and polynary landscape (e.g., distribution, variance, quantiles, max-min, etc)? -> Yes, G landscape is more smooth and concentrated (average pooling concentrate the distribution) -- will full S outperform full G for certainty? -> Full G > Full S -- will G and S with the same amount of knowledge perform differently? -> Partial G < Partial S -- will the performance always increase with increasing knowledge (tunable elements)
-> These conclusions are based on the average pooling. In other words, the payoff is randomly assigned (expectation is the same), rather than damage if decisions are not made. The difference is the variance, randomly generated values lead to higher variance, whereas average pooling lead to smaller variance. Yet, we believe smaller variance is more reasonable for modeling generalists and shallow understandings. This average pooling is coherent with the NK model, recalling the integration from FC into fitness; More importantly, normal distribution is common adopted in social phenomenon. This tradition are strongly built on normal distribution, unless strong reasons are provided (e.g., Levinthal's (2022) Organizational Task Environments). In this paper, we stay in the tradition of normal distribution. One can extend our model to explore the boundaries of this paper. -> If the assumptions are challenged, the conclusion may be different-> Partial knowledge is always harmful. Yet, there are many cases where one can stay ambiguious; In fact, this also resonate with the focusing problem-solving. In fact, if we release the scope constrains, G and S will continuous to improve their performance. Thus, we are not arguing that increasing knowledge is harmful. Instead, we are saying that tuning all the elements at the same time is harmful. Simplified caricatures help the search to jump out of the local traps. Thus, the question comes as to the trade-off between focusing and divergency. How many elements should generalists and specialists handles?
--recall the unknown domain shelter "*" -- If not applicable, may roll back to default value setups --Design separate CogLandscape class --Comparing the search trajectories among cog, ave, max, and min fitness values

MESSAGE.value: Update the previous code with the same agent setting
Reshape the project structure
Reduce the workload of gg_coordination
Add the exp of gg, ss under Priority
Unify the figure format
The second version of Coordination -- Two steps of proposer and evaluator structure.
Update the previous code --fix the search() function in specialist that using state instead of cog_state to determine the free space.
The second version of Priority --Update the priority_search function for both generalist and specialist
The second version of Topdown --Update the team search() function for all recombinations --Mutual alignment of solution and mindset
The third version of priority search --For specialists, fully adopt the elements of A/B from generalists; search from limited space afterward (e.g., A-> search from 0, 1)
The third version of Coordination --fix the bugs in specialist search (state vs cog_state in free space)

The third version of Coordination --fix the bugs in specialist search (state vs cog_state in free space)
The second version of Autonomy --fix the bugs in specialist search (state vs cog_state in free space)
Independent Search - N12
Update the figure format for AOM2023

option.name: LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE
option.value:
1. Simplify the model, Only two class: --Agent class for G/S/T --Landscape class for 4-state landscape
2. Agents all search on the finest landscape, just perceiving it from different perspectives. --adopt the default element design, resonating with the mindset and cognitive fixation; perhaps removed. --adopt the shelter "*" element design, resonating with the myopia induced ambiguity.
3. Introduce the different sub-area in the landscape, removed.
4. Adjust the ambiguity design --the average pooling algorithm now is much more informative and consistent with neighborhood perception.
